notes.text:
An update for kernel-rt is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.2 Extended Update Support.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The kernel-rt packages provide the Real Time Linux Kernel, which enables fine-tuning for systems with extremely high determinism requirements.

Security Fix(es):

* kernel: i40e: Do not allow untrusted VF to remove administratively set MAC (CVE-2024-26830)

* kernel: net/sched: Fix UAF when resolving a clash (CVE-2024-41040)

* kernel: mptcp: cope racing subflow creation in mptcp_rcv_space_adjust (CVE-2024-53122)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

notes.text: A flaw was found in Intel network adapters in the Linux kernel, where untrusted virtualized network interfaces can remove MAC addresses set by the system. This flaw allows an attacker with sufficient privileges to cause a denial of service.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: i40e: Do not allow untrusted VF to remove administratively set MAC
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: i40e: Do not allow untrusted VF to remove administratively set MAC

notes.text: A use-after-free vulnerability was found in the net/sshd tcf_ct_flow_table_process_conn of the Linux kernel. This flaw allows an attacker with a crafted payload to induce a system crash, resulting in a loss of system availability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: net/sched: Fix UAF when resolving a clash
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

Mitigation for this issue is either not available or the currently available options don't meet the Red Hat Product Security criteria comprising ease of use and deployment, applicability to widespread installation base or stability.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: net/sched: Fix UAF when resolving a clash

notes.text: A divide by zero flaw was found in the Linux kernel's Multipath TCP (MPTCP). This issue could allow a remote user to crash the system.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: mptcp: cope racing subflow creation in mptcp_rcv_space_adjust
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: By default, the MPTCP support is disabled in RHEL. This bug is only applicable if enabled.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

If enabled, you may disable MPTCP support. For more information please read https://docs.redhat.com/en/documentation/red_hat_enterprise_linux/8/html/configuring_and_managing_networking/getting-started-with-multipath-tcp_configuring-and-managing-networking#preparing-rhel-to-enable-mptcp-support_getting-started-with-multipath-tcp

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: mptcp: cope racing subflow creation in mptcp_rcv_space_adjust
